reviews.title: Not worth it
reviews.text: Fairly unpleasant and glad to leave. Nothing special to see if you have been to similar markets and a hassle when “guides” won’t leave you alone.

reviews.title: Eye Opening!
reviews.text: This market is both organized and chaotic. I'm sure that doesn't make too much sense but that's how I can describe it. It's like your typical market- fruits, vegetables, general goods, clothing- you name it. It's broken up in sections so all like items are within the same area. It's not for the faint of heart so you've never experienced outdoor markets from anywhere in the developing world, I suggest a guide or proceed with caution. It's safe, no one will bother you. It can be overwhelming and you may get some talkative vendors here and there. I felt very comfortable walking around with someone who was familiar with the do's and don'ts of the market, so I was very happy to have a guide. I learned a lot about the market through him as well. He even treated me to fruits, and showed me some less traveled areas in the market that I surely wouldn't have been able to easily do had I gone solo. If you're interested, his name is Kebba and he can be contacted via WhatsApp at +220 342 1046. I even contacted him on such short notice and he was able to arrange a tour for me within just a couple of hours! He's extremely professional, reasonably priced, excellent English speaking skills, and former Gambian military, so you're in very trusted hands.

reviews.title: ''Καλό''
reviews.text: Μεγάλη υπαίθρια αγορά που μπορείτε να ψωνίσετε τα πάντα σε σχέση με το σπίτι,φαγητό και για τους τουρίστες αν ενδιαφέρονται αναμνηστικά.Λατρεύουν το παζάρι στις τιμές!!

reviews.title: Great The Gambia Market For Everything
reviews.text:
We walked and shoppes through all the sections of this market that sells household goods, clothes, produce, fresh meats, spices, handicrafys and souvenirs. We could not resist fresh fruits, a souvenir shirt of The Gambia, and some good réplica of husos made into decor.  We spent time learning about various qualities, origins, and weaving componentes of colorgul fabrics.  
Vendors were generally pleasant with only a few marketing their goods with extra enthusiam. 
The market can be fun and can also have challenges.  Everyone speaks English. 
Delightful market

reviews.title: Gezelligheid kent geen tijd.
reviews.text: Gezellig/ lekker afdingen vergeet dit niet, dit is normaal / tijdstippen liefs in de ochtend i.v.m. warmte en drukte..

reviews.title: LIVELY ATMOSPHERE
reviews.text: We discovered Banjul, the capital of Gambia, located on St. Mary's Island. We explored the Albert Market, an urban treasure offering a variety of products and a lively atmosphere. Next, we visited Arch 22, a triumphal arch built to commemorate a coup d'état. This imposing structure offers panoramic views of the city and houses a museum. TRAVELWITHUS.COM FB AND INSTA AUTOURDOMONDE2023

reviews.title: Market visit Banjul
reviews.text: It’s a tourist market mainly . Very repetitive. But some nice hand made prices . You have to haggle but stuff is junk really. You cannot take photos of locals unless you buy from them. It is not safe to go alone as you get too much hassle and pick picketers . Our taxi driver accompanied us so no hassle at all. Didn’t buy  much but  nice to see locals selling their food. You can also see junta minutes island from there.

reviews.title: Bitter Kola
reviews.text: I like Gambians and the fact that they patronize us alot with our Nigerian BITTER KOLA. Love you guys

reviews.title: Smelly but good experience
reviews.text: Smelly and dusty but good experience. We visited this market with Buba tours. It was a nice experience to see the local stalls but be prepared for bad smell, mosquitos and people trying to attract your attention. We bought some wood crafts and cookies here. Visit this market with a good guide (like Buba tours) to find your way back out and to help you bargain at the prices.

reviews.title: A must see when visiting Banjul.
reviews.text: The Royal Albert Market is definitely worth a visit. I went with a guide who approached me. It was a good move because I was able to photograph almost everything, including the people. This wouldn't be possible otherwise. Photography is generally discouraged at markets. The market itself is manageable, and you can buy everything you need or don't need, including souvenirs and handicrafts. The guide wanted 800 dal for his services, which is obviously way too much. I gave 200 dal, and it was fine.

reviews.title: Nie ma rewelacji
reviews.text: Widzialem wiele rynkow w roznych częściach swiata. Ten pokazuje jak biedna jest Afryka ( choc Gambia z krajow afrykanskich ktore widzialem nie jest najgorsza).Masa chinskiej tandety .Zywnosc, owoce, mieso .Sprzedawane w warunkach takich jakie sa. Poprostu widac tu biede tego kraju.Owszem kupisz prawdziwe rekodziela ale to chyba jedyny plus tego rynku. Uwielbiam miejsca tego typu , ale to mnie przytloczylo. To jeszcze bardziej otwiera oczy na różnicę pomiedzy Europa i innymi czesciami swiata , a Afryka.

reviews.title: No point
reviews.text: Nothing to see except locals buying cheap Chinese rubbish and food. In a very crowded, hot and dirty environment. No lcal crafts or anything worth actually seeing. If you go in as a white person, you will be followed by some random Gambian people who will try and control where you go, engage in pointless conversation, ask for money etc. If you ignore them or don't engage, they will start shouting that you are racist and won't speak to black people. Avoid.

reviews.title: Good market
reviews.text: It's a good market for food, toiletries, fabric, fruits and crafts. I got some Sheabutter from the market

reviews.title: Besøg værd
reviews.text: Helt sikkert besøg værd. Man skal dog kunne klare den megen uro, lugt, manglende toiletter og desperate sælgere, som vil gøre hvad som helst for at få solgt.

reviews.title: Lokalt og fargerikt
reviews.text: Her tar du ikke med barna, til det er det litt for skittent og primitivt, men for en opplevelse! Fargerikt, lokalt marked der ting produseres på rangeeldags vis. I'll take a look at the "guide" so that it's a skull that has meg inn as a tourist destination, but I don't want to leave it behind. Kjempespenende å rusle rundt i den lokale delen av markedet! Ikke noe å kjøpe for meg ihvertfall men interesting å se.

reviews.title: Johan oli markkinat
reviews.text:
Todella isot markkinat. Pienet, kapeat ja mutkittelevat kujat. Täynnä erilaisia tuoksuja ja hajuja sekaisin kalan, lihan ja kaikkien muiden hajut. Kujat ovat katettuja ja ahtaita. Todella paljon kaikkea myynnissä. Vaatteita, ruoka tarvikkeita ja paikallisia käsitöitä.
Kannattaa ottaa paikallinen opas niin ei eksy.

reviews.title: Not for the faint hearted
reviews.text:
We had a free trip and choose among others The Albert Market.
Its big,busy ,sticks of fish but not to be missed,its Gambia the tourists dont see ,you could get lost there ,every one seems to be selling fish,vegetables and spices,oh dont go to the tourist part to get ripped of .
if you get the chance go but take a quide

reviews.title: Not famous.
reviews.text: Visited here this morning. The market itself isn't much to look at. Many stalls weren't open. The walk there was nice, though. Also, check out the beach behind the market.

reviews.title: Disgusting place
reviews.text: I've been to many markets in Africa, but none like this one: flies even on your clothes... The smell of sewage everywhere, dirt and garbage even at the food stalls. Rats at the meat and fish stalls. Terrible!

reviews.title: Tourist market, nice walk
reviews.text: A nice stroll through the market. Went here in conjunction with the Serekunda market. Spent the whole day with a taxi driver. It's quite convenient, so you don't have to worry about directions. The market is very touristy, but you can stroll around quite relaxed with your "private guide." Try the coffee. The craft market is also very nice, though the prices are touristy. As a result, I didn't end up buying anything, as prices were higher than back home. Beautiful products, especially made of wood. It's fun to see them. Definitely bargain hard. Tip: combine this with a visit to the Serekunda market. It's less touristy, if at all. While the taxi driver at the Albert Market said theft wasn't that common, now, as soon as you step out of the car, they told you to put your bag on your front. All in all, it's more relaxing to just not take anything with you, because it's incredibly crowded and you bump into everything and everyone. Narrow passageways in back streets. Buy a big bag of peanuts here if you still want to go to the monkey park!

reviews.title: Marknad med allt
reviews.text:
Albert market är en otroligt stor marknad, slingrande marknadsvaror som inte går att hålla koll på. Stora kontraster där det säljs upphittade begagnade saker till mer moderna. Träsniderier, läderarbeten mm.
Från underbara kryddofter och färsk frukt till enligt mig rutten fisk och härsket kött.
Pruta på allt, och ger dom inte med sig så gå vidare till nästa.
Ta gärna en guidad tur om ni ska hit.

reviews.title: The market of markets!
reviews.text: You can buy or find anything for sale there, absolutely anything. From refrigerators to fresh fish, from clothing to car parts. Many people offer all sorts of things, men, women, and children. Excellent English is spoken, which is helpful for negotiating. Get someone to guide you, like a taxi driver, because it's a maze squared. Have fun!

reviews.title: Authentic and colorful hustle and bustle
reviews.text: This open-air market is a must-see when visiting Gambia. Your senses will be intensely stimulated by the melee of scents, colors, and impressions. Practically everything is for sale here, from textiles, (household) utensils, spices and herbs, artisanal products, primarily wood carvings, to groceries including "fresh" fish and meat. Incidentally, there's no refrigeration of fish and meat here, and it happens at temperatures of up to 30 degrees Celsius. You'll need a strong stomach every now and then. I still remember the image of a handcart piled high with severed cattle heads, with a large pool of fresh blood underneath. Around it, a gigantic swarm of flying and crawling insects. Guidelines regarding hygiene and food safety, as we know them, will likely be unfamiliar here. The whole thing seems chaotic, with a huge crowd of people buying and selling in their colorful robes. It is recommended to take a guided tour. And even then, you have to slow down a bit. If you stand at a stall for a bit too long, you're expected to buy something. Of course, you can, but don't forget to haggle up to 30% of the asking price. Taking photos is frowned upon, even with a guide. Ask the people or do it with "prudence," i.e., don't zoom in on people but limit it to capturing the atmosphere. The demonstration we got on how to make pots, pans, spoons, and skimmers by melting down collected aluminum soda cans was especially interesting. I highly recommend visiting this market; nothing gives a better impression of daily life in Africa than this.

reviews.title: Zwiedzanie
reviews.text: Miejsce konieczne do zwiedzenia ale najlepiej z zaufanym lokalnym przewodnikiem. Można go znaleźć przed hotelem Atlantic pierwsze skrzyżowanie do miasta lub na plaży przy hotelu lub a najlepiej pytać o Alex/Willy Rasta często jest w corner obok hotelu poznasz po fladze polskiej.

reviews.title: definitely worth a visit
reviews.text: We visited this market with our taxi driver. It's a feast for the eyes. One section sells a huge variety of herbs, vegetables, and fish. Another section sells wood carvings, fabrics, and other items, rather than groceries. It's a feast for the eyes. The people are generally friendly. If you want to take photos, it's wise to check if they're open to it. We bought a small statue (wood carving) there. Remember to bargain. We ended up with a price almost 70% lower ;)

reviews.title: Myllrande marknad
reviews.text: Spännande marknad i den väldigt lilla huvudstaden Banjul. Här finns verkligen ett stort utbud, köpte själv en bordsduk och en hatt. Det är allt mellan himmel och jord som säljs, även mat som ligger ute i värmen och drar till sig flugor förstås. Men det var en trevlig upplevelse. Vi var inte så köpsugna dock, utan ville mest uppleva marknaden.

reviews.title: Trångt, mycket folk, interesting
reviews.text: Åkte dit då vi hade hört mycket om platen samt att vi ville känna hur pulsen var i det “riktiga” Gambia. Ska dock me en gång sägas att detta inte är den största marknaden det är i huvudstaden. Detta var en riktigt intressant upplevelse men personligen känner jag att räcker med att vara där en gång. Marknaden är verkligen för lokalbefolkningens dagliga behov och de bryr sig inte nämnvärt om turisterna som är där, tills du kommer till souvenirer! Det är mycket folk och varje kvadratmm används till försäljning. Det står saker precis överallt och precis allt säljs. I den gamla marknadsplatsen som sägs härleda till ett par hundra år tillbaka i tiden kan du nästan känna hur tiden dras tillbaka. På ett speciellt ställe finner du också kött- och fiskmarknaden och jag kan lugnt säga att den inte direkt klara av det svenska livsmedelsverkets riktlinjer. Här styckas köttbitar och fiskar rensas helt öppet med flugor precis överallt. Doften kan vara överväldigande för den som inte är beredd och det ligger köttslamsor lite överallt på golvet/marken. De färdigstyckade bitarna läggs sedan i frysar som fylls med is. Köper du kött läggs is i påsen med köttet för att bevara färskheten. Som jag skrev tidigare bryr sig inte säljarna om dig nämnvärt men detta ändras i samma sekund som du tar dig in i delen där de säljer souvenirer. Så snart du ens tanken på att beträda denna del hoppar samtliga säljare fram och vill ha in dig i just hans eller hennes försäljningsstånd. Det kan lätt bli lite svettigt då du blir väldigt passad. Men precisely som i övriga Gambia är det ingen som är otrevlig. Tvärtom! Alla är väldigt trevliga och vill dig bara väl, men de är också angelägna om att sälja. Jag rekommenderar att ta dig dit me local guide då du dels får det betydligt billigare än att åka med turisterna samt att du har in person som kan språket och möjligen också kan hjälpa dig att pruta. Bor du i närheten av Senegambia rekommenderar jag Bob som vi åkte med varje dag till lolika ställen samt att han även bjöd med oss två kvällar med hans vänner på reggaefester. Contact us by Whats App by nr +220 757 9974.

reviews.title: Real african market!!!!
reviews.text: I wandered around this market for a few hours. I couldn't see it all; everything was for sale, and hundreds of people were trying to sell their wares. Some got angry when I took pictures and demanded money. Among all the junk, clothes, and household items, you also found a butcher's shop. Maggots crawled across the floor, and everything was covered in thousands of flies. There were also many fish stalls in similar conditions. Definitely worth it.

reviews.title: Här finns allt att köpa !
reviews.text: En taxichaufför tog mig med på marknaden och han kände många som hade sina försäljningsställen på "Albert Market". Marknaden täcker en stor yta nära Gambiafloden.På Marknaden finns kläder -skor -konstverk -grönsaker och fisk bland annat.

reviews.title: Indoor market
reviews.text: A large market with plenty to offer. Don't expect high-quality products. Meat and fish are displayed unrefrigerated. And temperatures well above thirty degrees Celsius. Vegetables and herbs look good and fresh. It's lovely to wander among the stalls. This is also the place to have your clothes altered.

reviews.title: African market as an African market should be.
reviews.text: I spent a few hours there with a local as my guide. I was surprised by the sheer number of flies on the fish, but the guide told me that the fish had been swimming around that morning and were therefore incredibly fresh. Since the people don't have refrigerators, this is their way of keeping fish fresh. Just don't fry those few flies.

reviews.title: Albert Market
reviews.text: Not for the faint of heart or stomach. The smell makes you gag. Once you see it, you won't need it again.

reviews.title: The 3rd Market in Gambia
reviews.text: The Albert Market was our third market in Gambia. Souvenirs were a bit more expensive than the Bakau Craft Market. Otherwise, there's a good mix of things for locals and tourists. You can wander here without a guide without getting lost.

reviews.title: Quite nice
reviews.text: Albert Market is a must-visit for anyone visiting an African market for the first time. It's not large, and the stalls are manageable, but you still get a glimpse of handicrafts and fruit, vegetable, and fish sales. Those arriving by FTI bus probably won't see much, as about 40 people are herded through the narrow alleys that also serve as sales areas. It's best to arrive alone by taxi. Those seeking more excitement and bustle should head to Serekunda Market.

reviews.title: Excellent african market experience.
reviews.text: Watch your wallet gents. Ladies do not carry a handbag. Do NOT wear jewellery. ( you become a target). Professional PICKPOCKETS everywhere .Its like Fagin and Oliver Twist.. EVERY TRICK IN THE PICKPOCKETS BOOK. you would not believe it unless you experienced it.!!!

reviews.title: Fascinating
reviews.text: Very interesting and authentic! Even better with a local guide who shares some really interesting facts. Well worth it.

reviews.title: Big market
reviews.text: This Albert market is biggest market in Banjul and I think, it is biggest market in the whole Gambia. From here you can find allkind of souvenirs, shoes, clothes, fabrics, food etc. Market is under the metal roof (African style), so you can visit there also in Rain days.

reviews.title: Here you can find everything
reviews.text: A market where locals sell their goods, whether fruit, vegetables, or fish. There are several souvenir shops for tourists. There's even a sewing shop.

reviews.title: Day trip to the craft market
reviews.text:
If you like negotiating then you need to attend this market. Almost everything is up for negotiation. 

You’ll love it just like it did.

reviews.title: Authentic local market
reviews.text:
This is a very large local market, where you can buy anything.
The shop owners can see that you are a tourist, so if it is a fish shop they won't bother you, but those selling local clothes and handicrafts can be rather annoying. They don't take no for an answer.
Go with a local guide, or you may get lost.

reviews.title: African market
reviews.text: The Royal Albert Market in Banjul is a pure experience. It offers a vast array of typical African goods, from handicrafts to batik, jewelry, wood carvings, clothing, bags, fabrics of all kinds, and much more. Most of the goods sold in small stalls are still individually handcrafted. A must for every visitor to Gambia. However, one should not be afraid of direct contact with the always friendly vendors and should not be afraid of the sometimes narrow alleys between the stalls. Otherwise, it is advisable to visit the market with a local guide (e.g., a taxi driver).

reviews.title: Ett ställe som man aldrig glömmer
reviews.text:
Denna utflykt var spännande på alla vis. 

Tur att man hade guide med sig annars hade vi gått där än haha . 
Otroligt trångt med mycket intryck allt från lukter till känslor . 

Vi handlade en del saker man fick pruta rejält . 
Kan rekommendera TT åka dit.

reviews.title: Typical African market
reviews.text: A charming, typically African market where, in addition to food, many handmade items and other goods are for sale. The section with the many African tailors was a special experience. A wonderful tour, thanks to our guide.

reviews.title: Eye opening
reviews.text: This place was amazing. Our taxi driver took us here and showed us round. It was a really busy market selling everything but it's worth it more for the experience than to buy stuff.

reviews.title: En massa saker att köpa....
reviews.text: En marknadsplats med varor i mängder. Inte mycket att se förutom det. Trångt luktar mindre gott och försäljare som är på dig.  1 timme räcker för att se denna marknad som finns många liknande på andra platser.

reviews.title: Much nicer than Serakunda
reviews.text: A truly original market with only local people. Standard items like fish, fruit, meat, clothes, etc., are simply fun, and there's an excellent craft section where you can still find some beautiful things.

reviews.title: Myllrande marknad
reviews.text: Västafrikas största marknad. Tur att vi hade vår vän Salomon med oss annars hade vi nog virrat omkring än. Jag har ju varit på många marknader i världen den här var nog den mest färgrika. Alla dessa vackra textilier. Köpte endel men kunde köpt mer. Lokala killar kommer gärna och hänger sig på fast man har en inhemsk med sig. Men det hade nog varit fler om inte han varit med oss. Hjälpte till med prutning mm. Grönsaker, kryddor, fisk i mängder. Kunde gått där hela dagen. Får bli ett till besök där. Vi var inte på delen med hantverk, så det får vara nästa mål.

reviews.title: Albert Market
reviews.text: Рынок огорчил. Очень много китайского ширпотреба, причем все это висит, лежит, стоит на самых видных и приоритетных местах. Но, если углубиться в палатку и внимательно изучить товар, можно найти африканские текстильные изделия и деревянные поделки.

reviews.title: Noise from the locals
reviews.text: The famous Albert market of Banjul is one of the oldest in the country. This market was built by the British for trade to take place where locals can engage in all sorts of legal trade. It is a good spot if you want to enjoy real Gambian market life, with puzzling smiles and chants from sellers and buyers. It is one of the most visited places by tourists in the capital city of Banjul

reviews.title: you must have seen it
reviews.text: A super fun market where you can soak up the local atmosphere. Here you can buy nice things you won't find elsewhere in Gambia. It's also completely safe, but super busy.

reviews.title: Som vanligt....
reviews.text:
Ännu en av dessa marknader....
Det är alltid intressant att besöka marknader i länder man besöker för att få en inblick i folklivet. Albert Market var inget undantag men den skiljer sig inte från andra marknader jag besökt; mycket folk, rörigt, bökigt och samma utbud.

reviews.title: And superior man aldrig glömmer
reviews.text: And tell us that you can handle it better and be more comfortable with it because you are more than happy with your religion. går bra att pruta men man måste vara på sig om sitt pris ungefär 50% av deras pris kan man pruta. The next day you can still see the pastry at the same time.

reviews.title: Colorful markt in the open air ,
reviews.text: Colorful markt under a cloud filled with fruits and other products, .Besides food and chemistry, you will buy hand-sewn folk costumes here  and hand-made craft .Worth a visit .It  delights and encourages you to buy unforgettable handmade souvenirs .

reviews.title: Bustling colourful market
reviews.text:
Be prepared to haggle. Most stalls will start with a price 3 times what its worth so do haggle and you will get what you want at a price you want to pay. 
Lovely stall holders who can seem pushy but a no thank you usually does the trick.
Definetely worth a visit for the experience.

reviews.title: Typical African city market
reviews.text: This market is touted as the largest in Banjul. It’s best to go with a guide or someone that knows the place as it’s easy to get lost in the winding alleys and narrow ways. There’s lots to see and buy. It’s such a busy market with  everything under the sun, available. The sellers are quite pushy as everyone wants you to buy something from them. Thing is, all sellers start their prices very high and you must haggle for the best price. When you’re given a price, cut it below half and start haggling from there. Also be ready to walk away if you feel you’re being charged too much. It’s a bit like poker, sometimes with all the bluffing going on just to buy stuff but it’s part of the way of Albert market. Worth a visit to buy souvenirs and keepsakes.

reviews.title: with guide to be sure not to get lost
reviews.text:
Albert market is really a must see. It's big so getting lost is so easy. You are walking amongst sellers and buyers and the 'streets' are really narrow which makes it easy to get claustrophobia. taking pictues is really hard here because being so narrow the sellers do notice you taking a pic which they don't like at all. So be aware that they shout towards you or even are taking something to throw at you. 

We did it wit our guide Mamadi from Checkpoint Charlie tours. No stress, his task is to protect and serve and even walking at amongst the fishers on the beach gave you a save feeling. Don't forget to do that too. 

It's dirty and smelly, count on that but what a joy to visit.

reviews.title: Autentisk
reviews.text: And authentic besøg på Albert market i Banjul. Her er en masse indtryk for alle sanser. Besøg gerne markedet med en en localguide. OBS. Her er meget dårlige toiletforhold Man skal kunne klare “lugten” i de områder de sælger kød. Alle vil gerne sælge, det kræver en del afvisninger, men bestemt et besøg værd!

reviews.title: Banjul market
reviews.text: Best way to get here is to get a fixed price with a guide to help you navigate the market. It is huge and the risk of getting lost is big. It is not very touristy and you have everything from leather, to carpentry, tailoring and fish. The market has everything and try to stay calm. It can be quite stressful with all of the salesmen trying to get your attention. Therefore the guide is essential, even though he leads you to his companions in the market it helps. We went in the afternoon on a Monday and were practically the only people there. It was very special, I wouldn't say you have to see it.

reviews.title: Прикольно по африкански
reviews.text:
Африкпнская красота и колорит. Надо посетить. Купили, все что хотели , и даже что не хотели. 
Ну классно. 
Торговцы пристают сразу и много м естных попрошаек, но это не напрягает, если есть минимально опыт подобных стран.  Центральный рынок. От атлантика по берегу 10 минут

reviews.title: A real treat
reviews.text: Well there was everything here, all manner of smells - good and bad, people, sounds, things for sale and some astounding sights. Barter hard for a bargain

reviews.title: Interesting and busy
reviews.text: Go here to see some of the local life and understand how life in a third world country can be. Bring a guie or a trusted local if you feel insecure when being approached by bumsters. Most people here are really nice. Ask before taking pictures, som people will say no, ofters will be happy to pose for you (and do not charge). Some will even encourage you to take pictures of or with them. Be aware that this is a busy and sometimes dirty and smelly place so do not dress in your best clothes.

reviews.title: Hyper-busy market in the center of Banjul
reviews.text: You have to be confident, everyone wants something from you, of course, but if you persevere you get a great insight into the daily madness of this market.

reviews.title: Kleurrijk
reviews.text: Leuke markt waar je als toerist leuke dingen kunt kopen. Wel afdingen. Loop ook over de levensmiddelen markt, deze is wat authentieker.

reviews.title: Give it a try
reviews.text: Orderly and easy to navigate.  Alot better and cleaner than the market in serekunda. IF you are looking for it most likely it is in albert market, and the prices are reasonable.

reviews.title: Worth a visit if you are in Banjul
reviews.text: We visited as a couple but with a guide - so pleased we did as I imagine I might get lost in the alley ways. Our guide also assisted us in taking photographs - the locals were not keen on the camera - but he stopped at a few stalls and bought some fresh ingredients for his evening meal - as he got into conversation with the stall holders we were then able to take some candid shots without offending. It's a warren of narrow allies, some stalls covered with bright sun umbrellas and some stalls in the covered market. All sorts on sale from the enormous smoked fish being sold from a wheel barrow to Sunday dresses and flip flops. Of course the usual fruit and veg. It's even possible to have a shirt tailor-made - several guys working away at their sewing machines at the back of the market. We spent half an hour here - could have easily stayed longer

reviews.title: Good local market
reviews.text: While the Albert market does have its share of mask/souvenir shops it is also a place for locals with fish, vegetables, fruits, ancient grains and prepared foods on offer. It is not particularly clean but it was not intimidating at all. We were happy to be in a place that didn't feel like it was only for tourists.

reviews.title: Not as full-on as serrekunda
reviews.text: And thats a good thing sometimes. Albert Market has all the usual tourist-trap shops but is a working market and caters to the locals' needs, both domestic and commercial. A must is the fishing-village part just around the corner form the market - again, a real, working place, tricky to walk around but an essential visit if you want to experience something other than hordes of tourists clicking away.

reviews.title: The real gambia
reviews.text: Instead of the serrekunda market we went with our driver to albert market. Which is in the middle of the city center. They have various little shop. Dont expect to much. You see gambian selling food, fruit and clothes. You see the normal day of life where the heart beats. Also close to the ferries.

reviews.title: Koe aidot afrikkalaiset markkinat!
reviews.text: Kannattaa ehdottomasti käydä pääkaupungin suurimmilla markkinoilla Albert Marketissa ja tutustua markkinoiden tarjontaa, tinkimistä unohtamatta! Myyjän antamasta ensimmäisestä hinnasta voi tinkiä 40-50% pois.

reviews.title: Busy and cozy market
reviews.text: I took this trip with Falutours. I first went to Serrekunda market, which is very different, with lots of clothes for sale, but it's also very pleasant.

reviews.title: Jobbigt och rörigt
reviews.text: Barnen tyckte det var hemskt, jag också. Folk drug i en, en del blev sura och arga för attt man inte besökte deras stånd. Väldigt smutsigt, obehaglig stämning, trångt och rörigt. En väldig labyrint och helt plötsligt hamnade man utanför. Gambia överlag är inte särskilt bra på att hantera sopor och här märks det tydligt. Det luktar hemskt och stranden är skitig och nedskräpad. Vi åkte hem till hotellet ganska omgående. Här är nog ett måste att du har en guide med dig, vi hade vår Yakob som tog hand om oss hela veckan, han vallade runt oss.

reviews.title: Intensivt myller
reviews.text: Härlig marknad med intensivt myller. Här har jag shoppat barnkläder i afrikanska tyger, träsniderier, korgar mm. Här säljs även matvaror. Alla är på dig och vill visa sina varor och allt ska prutas.

reviews.title: Nice experience,
reviews.text: Bargaining is encouraged. Friendly people, even if you don't buy anything. A world of difference from North Africa, where you're accosted and never let go.

reviews.title: Bigger market, lots of clothes
reviews.text: It's lovely to wander through, especially the fabrics and herbs. You won't be bothered too much. It's great for exploring on your own, not so big that you'll get lost.

reviews.title: Beautiful here
reviews.text: It's so nice to walk here, it's a bit messy, but that's how it should be here and the people are really friendly and not pushy.

reviews.title: Nice!
reviews.text: Well worth a visit! Don’t forget to negotiate the price when you’re there. Not very big, but a nice experience with opportunity for shopping.

reviews.title: A must-see spot
reviews.text:
This is the main market in the city and is a hive of activity. There are shops on either side of the main street, but the market itself is off to one side and is a rabbit-warren of alleyways and stalls. You'll find just about everything on sale here but it is a great place to buy souvenirs. Some really good and colourful material on offer.

There are loads of sights and sounds. You'll probably find that young (and some not so young) men will offer to guide you around. It is probably worth accepting the offer of one of them, otherwise you'll find yourself pestered constantly and you simply won't be left alone to wander at your leisure. All they expect is a few Euros or dollars at the end of your visit.

Remember that bartering is near-mandatory here. A good gauge is to pay about one third of what the seller first asks for. Be persistent. If you start to walk away, your offer will generally be accepted. Even so, things are good value and, generally, good quality.

You cannot visit Banjul without coming here.

reviews.title: A revisit with a local and some serious shopping...
reviews.text: And she knew where to go, what she was looking for and what to pay.  Always of interest to me the colours the smells the bussle of activities. Got herbs and spices, house goods and bike bits lot cheaper that supermarket, cloth apparently better bought at Serrekunda, photos to follow.

reviews.title: It is a big market area...lots of walking around....
reviews.text: Yes...worth a visit for as short or as long as you wish.  Colourful and stimulating smeliferous.  Everything under the sun!  Much less hassle if you use a guide/escort for this part of a visit to Banjul.  Walk the fish market area and beach...including the to and fro for the local ferry boats.

reviews.title: Eye opening
reviews.text: A real insight into Africa. A must do experience for all the family. Not much to buy but great to see. Make sure you take a guide with you.

reviews.title: Local market
reviews.text: A large market selling food, clothing, house hold goods and live stock. It is a worth a visit to soak up the sights, sounds and smells. If you have a taxi here, your driver will probably show you around.

reviews.title: Targ afrykański
reviews.text: Każdy, kto będzie w Banżul powinien zobaczyć to miejsce. Można tu kupic dosłownie wszystko, od żywności po stroje czy też pamiątki. Atmosfera jest tu specyficzna i zapach też:) Jest bardzo, bardzo kolorowo.

reviews.title: Pala aitoa Afrikkaa
reviews.text: Oltiin Timo toursin retkellä Senegalin eläinpuistossa, käytiin tullessa piipahtamassa Albert marketissa. Ostettiin puuveistoksia niitä oli hyvät valikoimat, tinkiä kannattaa hinnasta 2/3 osaa ainakin pois. Kannattaa ainakin jotain ostaa, valikoimaa on tosi paljon. Käytävät ovat sokkeloisia ja melko ahtaita. Afrikan tuoksuja ja hajuja, tämä pitää kaikkien kokea jotka tänne asti tulevat.

reviews.title: Your typical African Market
reviews.text: Just your typical African Market. Largest in Banjul but small when compared to some of the markets in my home country. Would be of great interest to Europeans. I was able to buy some local print shirts and dresses as souvenirs.

reviews.title: Albert Market
reviews.text: A local market in downtown Banjul.it is a daily crowded noisy busy market with cramped aisles like a maze.it sells everything & anything.not for the faint hearted. The main post office is on the same street.worth a visit to see activity.

reviews.title: Interesting but a bit hostile
reviews.text: It's not that I'm unused to this type of crowded market or the usual insistent insistence of its vendors, but I don't know if it's a coincidence or if it's true, but I found some of the staff particularly caustic and impertinent. Still, the place is a good place to visit.

reviews.title: To get lost
reviews.text: A local crafts market with fantastic stalls, where haggling is part of the market's inner life. Located in the heart of Banjul. A must-see for anyone visiting Gambia.

reviews.title: INTERESTING
reviews.text: Albert Market is something to see. It is quite large and is very cramped. The aisles are extremely narrow. It is one of those market that purely shows you the way of life of the Gambian people. They sell old clothes, fish (mostly covered in flies), vegetables, nuts, household bits and pieces, cotton fabric and a bit of everything in between. You can even have some clothes made for you there as you will find some very talented dressmakers. This market will be a bit of a challenge for those who suffer crowds, noise and at time bad smell. Try to go in the afternoon as it is less crowded. If you find something that attracts your fancy, don't forget to bargain... cut in half or more the price offered and get to a point that you are both happy with. Happy hunting.

reviews.title: digusting, full of flies, not worth visiting
reviews.text: 1. It was like any market in the world that had all the products there. The difference was that this one was truly disgusting. Fruits were rotting, there were thousands of flies everywhere. 2. The people can be pretty annoying too. They hiss at you and try to call you in, but in a rude matter. 3. No real places to eat and if you want to eat a clean meal, don't ever eat here. You might even get cholera if you are not careful. Seriously, don't waste your time and energy visiting, unless you have nothing to do and have time to kill.

reviews.title: Specially worth visiting but...
reviews.text: Visiting the market is definitely a must-do if you're there, but during the rainy season (now, of course), you have to accept the stinking air, the millions of free flies, and the filthiness of everything. But it's truly special to visit. I've gotten used to a lot of things from all the traveling, but this is intense, so be prepared.

reviews.title: The real Gambia
reviews.text: This market is definitely worth a visit if you want to get to know the real Gambia, there is plenty to buy and the people are very friendly.

reviews.title: The 'Royal Albert' always worth a visit if in Banjul and an hour to spare.
reviews.text: Might be serious shopping for the initiated, fish, fruit and veg, fabrics or a browse around the many craft stalls at the back. Always a bargin to be had with a bit of negotiation and this time of year some real photo treats as the Gambians go about their daily routine, in colourful dress and close to Ramadam.

reviews.title: Handbag shopping
reviews.text: At the back of Albert market is the craft market is the craft area. We picked up a beautiful handbag and leather bracelet as well as a great piece of cloth all at the right price

reviews.title: a go to place to shop for just about anything
reviews.text: Albert Market, Banjul is indeed the go to place to buy anything, be it local art curios, local fabrics or readymade clothes, shoes and knic knacs. The advantage - you can find all of it in one place. The disadvantage - for people not comfortable with crowds, it can be a bit of an exercise. Vendors will call out, ask you what you want, show their wares. A lot of goods are cheap copies of famous brands but some shops also do keep originals if you have a keen eye. All in all a world in itself if you are unfraid to explore its winding by lanes. Happy Hunting!!

reviews.title: Bazar market
reviews.text: Wyglad Targ niczym w polsce tylko wiecej owocow egzotyk.super pokazane to na fotkach tego serwis duzo moZna sie dowiedziec.nim sie pojedzie zycie tam z tego co wiem od znajomy net z tad Tania jedynie dla turystow bedzie drogi lot.

reviews.title: IL MERCATO
reviews.text: Davvero autentico questo mercato nella piccola città di Banjul merita una visita per rendersi conto di come vivono gli abitanti del più piccolo stato dell'Africa

reviews.title: A bit touristy but good and well-organized
reviews.text: Nice market in Africa's sleepiest capital, stroll through the clothing and food market and trade at the craft market

reviews.title: Lovely market with great people
reviews.text: Lovely market with fantastic people their was a lot to choose from the carvings were brilliant I did  uy a few but it was very hot when myself and my husband went the locals are very friendly the don't try and rip you of that's what I like I just name my price and this it but definitely worth a visit.

reviews.title: Nice market with adjacent shopping street
reviews.text: Albert Market is a smaller market with a wide variety of items. If you bargain well, you can get good prices. I usually ended up with a third or sometimes a quarter of the opening price. For smaller items up to 100 dalassi (€2), I didn't bother. The people speak good English. I bought a handmade djembe there (65 cm high and 35 cm in diameter) weighing about 9 kilos with a great sound and a bag included. Exiting the market leads to a "neat" shopping street. Serekunda Market is three times larger, busier, and the prices are comparable.

reviews.title: Typical visit to the city of Banjul
reviews.text: The capital, Banjul, has "little" to visit, but the market is one of those places where locals go to do their daily shopping and you can see the fruits, foods... The best thing is the craft area, although a little scarce compared to the Brikama market.

user.name: arquicarel
user.location: Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain

reviews.title: Klimat dawnej Afryki
reviews.text:
Miejsce jest bardzo specyficzne. Kolorowe, tętniące życiem, duszne i śmierdzące jednocześnie. Przypomina mi nasz stadion X lecia w wydaniu lokalnym. Turyści są tam mile widziani pod warunkiem, że coś kupują. Łatwo tam znaleźć coś dla siebie. Ja kupiłem suszone kwiaty hibiskusa na herbatę, pyszne owoce baobabu i jeszcze jakieś super nawilżające masło shea. Inni brali koszulki, pareo, wyroby z drewna. Z całą pewnością warte odwiedzenia bez względu jak je ocenicie. 
Sprzedawcy nieco nachalni za to z podstawami polskiego.

reviews.title: Intensivt och komprimerat Gambia
reviews.text: Färger, dofter, människor från många olika miljöer och sociala förhållanden samlas på denna marknad. En till plats man inte ska missa!

reviews.title: Kaikkea !
reviews.text: Täältä löytyy kaikenlaisia käsitöitä. Sokkeloinen markkinapaikka täynnä iloisia myyjiä. Tinkiminen on osa kaupantekoa. Hinnasta pois 80% ainakin!

reviews.title: Real local market
reviews.text:
A peek into a real local experience of a market. Knowing that you won't be getting your groceries there, the people at the market don't hassle you but go about their way as usual. You can sit and have a drink at the end, and of course there's stalls where you can buy souvenirs.

I wouldn't venture in here alone, so coming with a guide would probably be best.

reviews.title: Guided tour from Kololi's Senegambiabeach hotel
reviews.text: Great experience to be in this "indoor" market with so many friendly people with many types of merchandise in a shopping environment

reviews.title: Market
reviews.text: Very interesting but very smelly and a lot of flies wouldn't go there on your own as quite scary don't think I would buy food, we went more for fabrics and gifts, and only pay 1/3 what they ask for.

reviews.title: Amazing place
reviews.text: Very interesting to see but very very busy , the shop owners are very pushy which can be a bit to much at times. Very interesting to see items being made although the fish can be very smelly and full of flies.  Amazing to see all the items on sale and a real look at gambian people and there life.

reviews.title: Bustling African market selling everything
reviews.text: This is the oldest & largest market in Banjul.  Here you can buy everything from food to household goods, and also local crafts.  Although Gambia is fairly safe, watch your purse or wallet.  Haggling is a must.  The craft shops will be very persistent but simply ask them to give you room and time to decide.  Many people do not want their photos taken so you need to ask first or be quick.

reviews.title: Banjul Market
reviews.text: A fantastic experience at the Banjul Market. Lots of different products, lots of colors, and good prices, ranging from African clothing and jewelry to vegetables and wood carvings and hair products. Those who can negotiate are welcome here; otherwise, bring a guide.

reviews.title: אחלה מקום לקניות לכול המשפחה
reviews.text: מקום נהדר לקנו. הכל... בגדים לכולם להורים לאחים לילדים ולעצמנו בעיקר... בנוסף תכשיטים שעונים פרחים שעושים יפה בעין.... לאיקר יחסית לקניונים בסביבה ממש קונים הכל באווירה נעימה ובמחירים סבירים ונהנייים... מוממלץ

reviews.title: Gambia in general, we loved it
reviews.text: Incredible place, phenomenal people, no complaints at all. We went on many excursions with a guide and a 4x4, we had a blast. They have phenomenal beaches. The markets are amazing.

reviews.title: watch out for the bumsters
reviews.text:
We tried to visit the market at our own, but Always hassled by different locals who wanted to be our guide, who knows the things always better and who are only intreseted in the tip.
The food market is different, don't mind the thousands of flies and the odeur.
Prices are rather high.

reviews.title: Albert market
reviews.text: Awful scary place. Full of bad smells and desperate people trying to make a living 😦😱😱👃We did buy a beautiful mask and met a holy man . Not somewhere I would return unlike Gambia itself. We have returned since Albert Market and enjoy other parts of Gambia

reviews.title: Gambian shopping Center
reviews.text: If you are curious about a classical african market you may have a short look because of bad smelling. You can buy some simple sovanuir for friends.

reviews.title: Afrika på en timme!
reviews.text: Här blandas alla dofter, och färger i ett enormt skådespel. Kvinnorna gör sina dagliga inköp av färsk fisk och grönsaker.

reviews.title: Atmosphere guaranteed
reviews.text: Since most Gambians don't own a refrigerator, they shop at the market every day. Take a stroll and immerse yourself in the authentic atmosphere, filled with colors and scents.

reviews.title: Härlig marknad
reviews.text: Väldigt stort, väldigt mycket att handla, väldigt billigt, pruta pruta pruta :) Vi åkte dit med lokal guide och kände oss väldigt trygga. Människorna är så trevliga och det är lätt att trivas. Absolut värt att åka dit! Man behöver mycket tid eftersom det är så stort

reviews.title: Chaotic but a very interesting experience
reviews.text: The smells (mostly pleasant) and the chaos makes this market an experience I shall never forget, but would definitely recommend if you need to be there to take it all in. You walk over rough ground through narrow channels between the traders and their stalls. They all call out to you to come and look at their wares and will almost plead with you to buy something and immediately start dropping the price even if you tell them you aren't buying, only looking. You have to be firm and walk away. I found it quite annoying because I really wanted to take my time and brouse properly. I might have actually spent more if I hadn't felt quite so hassled, but it's just a totally different culture. We had a guide with us who stepped in when he could tell we'd had enough of the hard-sell. I don't think I would have liked to go it alone! Not sure I'd want to go back either, which is a shame, but it's just not for me. As I said at the beginning though, don't be put off - go experience for yourself!

reviews.title: African market with all the noise and hassle
reviews.text: A very large market where you can find just about anythings from vegetables, jewellery, shoes to chickens and fish. Its easy to get lsot so dont turn away a self-invited guide, who will tell you he doesnt want money but at the end of the "tour" will complain you dint give him enough.

reviews.title: Surprised with this market wonderful place
reviews.text: Nice to mix with the locals who are all very friendly and polite. Varied market from carvings to general shopping and not expensive. Pleasant to just walk and grouse through the stalls and not being pushed into buying. Very memorable experience a must to visit

reviews.title: Ett måste
reviews.text:
Ett måste att besöka denna marknad. Men var beredd på att de vill sälja ! !
Påstridiga men charmen på marknaden överväger allt. Ett måste dock! 
Pruta, Pruta, Pruta

reviews.title: Albert Market w Banjul
reviews.text: Albert Market w Banjul, to pełen życia , kolorowy, afrykański targ. Handel trwa tu praktycznie przez cały czas, ciągle pojawiają się świeże produkty : owoce, ryby, skóry, meble , artykuły codziennego użytku. Tutaj można kupić turystyczne pamiątki jak również kartki pocztowe wraz ze znaczkami oraz wymienić pieniądze.

reviews.title: Tam możesz kupić piękne orginalne rękodzieło :-)
reviews.text:
Odpowiednie miejsce jeżeli szukasz niesztampowej pamiątki z Afryki.
Są tam trzy stoiska z prawdziwymi perełkami .
Piękne maski używane w obrzędach oraz okiennice i figurki
Polecam spróbować również Cat Fish wędzonej palce lizać

reviews.title: The Real Gambia
reviews.text:
Visited as part of a 4 in 1-day tour with The Gambia Experience. 
This daily market is a fabulously chaotic mix of colours, smells and movement with people going about their daily lives in a maze of narrow lanes. With so many traders it’s amazing that most people manage to scrape a living!
Bartering is the name of the game. Tourist can expect to end up paying what is the starting price for the locals!
A great experience and well worth a visit.
TOP TIP
Be courteous, always ask if you can take photograph of traders and their stalls. These are dignified people, not theme park extras.

reviews.title: Worth a look
reviews.text:
Worth a look, but not overly impressed. The prices are much more than the local markets you find and a lot of the items are not as well finished. However it is a good experience and as always you will meet a lot of friendly locals! I would recommend taking a guide/driver in with you to stop most of the hassle you get. 
Good fun and interesting to see how other cultures live and shop! 
The hustle and bustle of Gambian lifestyle!

reviews.title: Traditonal and colourful market
reviews.text: This is a traditional and hassle free market where you cab see how Gambia people shop, the produce available and experience the colour and bustle of real daily life in the area. There is a small craft market but the general humdrum and vibrancy of the market is the real attraction

reviews.title: Banjul's most interesting offering
reviews.text: We took a taxi from our Kotu hotel and, on arrival, our driver unexpectedly got out of the car to come with us - so glad as we got to see things we'd otherwise have missed - in particular the areas where the fish catch is brought in and, next to it, where the fish is smoked. We were also able to browse at our leisure without any of the usual requests to look in every stall. We've been lucky to see many similar markets around the world and always find it very interesting (once we've put aside our squeamishness!!) to watch how local people shop and what for. Our driver was stunned when he showed me the huge baskets full of oysters and I told him how much oysters can cost back home.

reviews.title: Authentic Gambia
reviews.text: This local market you have to see. You really get a glimpse of the locals' everyday life. Take a local guide with you.

reviews.title: Rynek
reviews.text: Super klimaty. Kolor, różnorodność,  zdziwienie 😲,  zapach. Nie za bardzo handlujący lubią gdy się ich fotografuje ;-) Kup coś a zrobisz świetne zdjęcie.

reviews.title: Good Market!
reviews.text: We went as a group and this market was a good market! Good prices (that you barter for) good variety of stalls and the locals are all very nice! We were stuck between going to this Market and the Serekunda Market but we decided on this one! Not sure what the Serekunda Market is like but this one was great for what we needed!

reviews.title: visit Albert Market
reviews.text: A unique market, with an inflated asking price—a third of which is the normal price. Don't buy food here; it's a nice souvenir.

reviews.title: Visit if it is the only market you have a chance to see
reviews.text: The area is alive with people, smells, and life.  I come to just walk through the area and ignore the vendors trying to sell most anything you can think of.  Having a local guide is helpful to guide you through the maize of paths.  Guides often help keep the people from hassling you.  While the meat and fish area may be smelly and upsetting for some, it is worth a visit.  This is one area in the country I had to be careful with taking photos.  The other side of the market opens to the beach area where you can see the larger boats and small boats unloading what they have brought in.  The market is Banjul at work!

reviews.title: very cozy atmosphere
reviews.text: Great market to visit, all the colours and fresh fruit are delicious, you also see things that are really not possible here, but that is why you are in Africa and not in the Netherlands

reviews.title: Marker....
reviews.text: Plac targowy na którym można wiele kupić, dużo sprzedawców bardzo zachęcających do kupienia ich towaru ufff bardzo męczące :-)

reviews.title: a real eye opener
reviews.text: lots of hustle and bustle very vibrant great fun haggling for goods that you buy (please haggle because the trader love this and treat it like a game) many bargains to be had. i would advise you to miss the fish and meat market section it really stinks and swarms of fly but other then that was great fun

reviews.title: An explosion on the senses
reviews.text:
Go to the food market early in the morning (i think it opens at 8): everyone is too busy to bother with you, so for a brief time you'll be ignored and free to pass through unmolested and without being stopped by hawkers. The temperature is also much more tolerable at that time, and there are no other tourists. 
The sights and smells are not altogether pleasant, but a great taste of africa!

reviews.title: A real eye opener
reviews.text: A very interesting morning seeing different crafts and an insight into the daily life of the locals.Watched all the fish coming off the boats before being taken to the market to be sold.

reviews.title: Last minute shopping
reviews.text: I go to Gambia every year, and I always visit this market in the last few days to have a look around and do some last-minute shopping... The area of the market is more touristy, so it's better not to go there if you don't want to buy... Like in almost all markets for "guiris" they tell you to just look and you end up buying... Hehe

reviews.title: You can't miss this
reviews.text: Busy, but lively. Chaotic, but fun. The must-see market is divided into three sections: the local market, the tourist market, and the fruit and vegetable market. It's fun to see, and if you want something, you need to be a good bargainer, otherwise you'll overpay. Without a guide, you're lost, but as soon as you get out of the taxi, there are people waiting to show you around.

reviews.title: Interesting place to see
reviews.text: The craft market is very interesting and has amazing handicrafts. Always remember to bargain! The sellers are trying to get visitors' attention all the time, which is somewhat annoying. Having a local with you might help as he can show around but it doesn't help with noisy sellers.

reviews.title: Really local market
reviews.text: Small streets. Many choises. It is best to have someone local with you. You can loose your directions. Worth to see. It shows Gambling.

reviews.title: A highlight of you visit to Banjul
reviews.text: As above a highlight to your visit to Banjul , Been several times , just back JAN 16 ,, originally went with a Juice Boys from the Lacio as can be a bit daunting if never been before , however now visit un escorted ( they seem to know if you have been before ) and just a polite no will do . so deff give a visit it is a eye opening experience

reviews.title: Intressant
reviews.text: Intressant men något jobbigt, när alla säljare drar  i en och vill sälja sina saker. När vi är fyra i familjen var det lite svårt att hålla ihop.

reviews.title: Colorful
reviews.text: A really fun, busy, and hectic market. It's also very colorful, with all the vegetables sold here, usually sitting on the floor among the fish that's also there... very cozy too.

reviews.title: Go early before it's too budy
reviews.text: This is a lively market used by locals, there was lots of food and flies, boys operating sewing machines as fast as lightening, many examples of local crafts, a guide of your choosing saves the hassle of being followed around by an opportunist who will want money for guiding you, we used the taxi driver, not really big enough to get seriously lost though, everyone wants you to look at their stall, bartering essential!

reviews.title: Pruta!!
reviews.text:
Kul marknad med massor av olika saker att titta på.
Pruta minst 50 % om du ska köpa något.
Det kan kännas lite jobbigt när alla försäljare sliter och drar i dig dock.

reviews.title: Go with a Local
reviews.text: When we arrived at Albert Market we were already with a friend, but another "market guide" came up and offered to show us around as well. It was helpful having others that know good prices as they helped us bargain. The craft vendors especially will try to get the best of you and are much more aggressive than the other vendors. Be firm in your prices; they may try and tell you that they're losing money if they give it to you for the price you've suggested but of course it isn't true. For a small wooden figurine or a flashy beaded necklace for example, 100 Dalasi each is sufficient. For a beach wrap, expect to pay approximately 200 Dalasi. At the end of our market excursion our market guide asked us for some money to buy a drink with, so expect to tip if you allow his services.

reviews.title: Pleasant hustle and bustle
reviews.text: A visit to the Albert Market is definitely worthwhile for anyone who's never been. It's recommended to go with a guide.

reviews.title: Almost a must
reviews.text: In Gambia you of course should visit a market. This one is big, a bit touristy but not too obtrusive. If you're prepared for a more genuine market (almost no tourists, smells, dirt, atmosphere!) go to Serrekunta...

reviews.title: Dip yourself in African smells and colours
reviews.text: Great place to taste Gambian folklore at its pure, harsh version. Especially worth visiting is its handicraft sector.

reviews.title: You definitely have to see this!!!
reviews.text: We visited Albert Market and thoroughly enjoyed it. If you take your time, you'll see just about anything here. They sell vegetables, fruit, meat, fish, fabrics, household goods, shoes, and lots of wooden items—simply too much to list. It's definitely worth taking a leisurely stroll through. Be sure to bring a guide; we were the only "Toubabs" (white Europeans) there, and that's not very comfortable without a guide. They often get angry when you try to take photos. This is frowned upon because they think the photos will be sold. Fortunately, after some explanation, it's allowed. We think Albert Market is a must-see if you're on holiday in Gambia.

reviews.title: not as crazy as Serekunda market!
reviews.text: Albert market caters for tourists and visitors more than the huge and bustling Serekunda market, but there is plenty to see and smell as locals go about their lives and the place is full of jostle and banter

reviews.title: Lots to see
reviews.text: Go with a guide or you'll get lost. Don't take photos without permission. Negotiate until you drop.

reviews.title: Not for the Fainthearted
reviews.text:
I had fun at this market, which is actually called Albert Market. It is not the usual kind of fun and you need to understand that it can be full of people on some days. Also understand that depending on where you go in the market, there can be strong smells of fish and meat, with flies in abundance sitting on the fish mainly. The market feels a little chaotic but if you go with someone who knows it, it is not bad. Do not expect to be wowed with amazing arts and crafts. This is a true third world market and some of the streets you might walk through are muddy with stones and holes randomly distributed. If you know where to go, you can also see a beach close to the market where boats arrive to sell their fish first to people waiting on the beach. You will also be able to see from this beach where the Atlantic Ocean and the Gambia River meet.

If you are not sure if this market is for you, ask yourself if you have seen a few third world countries and markets before. If you have, it should not phaze you. However, if this is your first experience of a third world country, it might come as a complete and overwhelming culture shock to you. Perhaps ask a taxi driver to walk with you and, if you feel you want to get out of there, you can then let the driver know. At least that way you have a quick escape.

reviews.title: Good market to visit
reviews.text: A better market than Serrecunda, not so much pressure or crowds, lovely to see all the colours and to smell all the different smells, and good to have a good barter for something.

reviews.title: Be brave.....
reviews.text: dear traveler. Be good. The sights, the sounds, the smells can all be over-whelming and the hangers-on (bumsters in the local parlance) who will magically appear, can be a total pain in the posterior --- but be brave. Grit your teeth, ignore the bumsters, and go your own way, and you won't be disappointed......... but time it right. To do the market justice you must allow 2 to 3+ hours and in the heat it can get stiff, so time your visit for either very early in the morning or the late afternoon, and don't forget your water!

reviews.title: 신기한 볼거리 가득
reviews.text: 직모를 가지고 싶어하는 아프리카 사람들의 심리로, 가발이 많이 진열되어 있어요^^ 고소한 견과류와 함께 둘러보면 좋아요~

reviews.title: Go here if you are brave
reviews.text: The smells are overwhelming here. Very lively place to see plenty of things you could buy, if you would live a life here in Banjul.

reviews.title: Banjul Market
reviews.text: the market is an eye opener - but do not go with out a guide!!   you will just get hassled from the bumsters.   we brought some wooden carvings - but remember to haggle, do no pay the price asked.   its a very different world out there but the people are lovely

reviews.title: A cozy market with loving people
reviews.text: This market is a real asset to the village, with fruit, clothing, jewelry, and paintings made right there. Seamstresses busily craft the most beautiful dresses and blouses. I had a lovely two-piece suit made from satin fabric, a blouse and skirt. I'm incredibly happy with it. The people are incredibly friendly. Do bring a guide from the hotel. Some people can be pushy, but with a guide, you won't have that problem.

reviews.title: Bara positiva upplevelser. Monkey park måste upplevas.
reviews.text: Gambia är ett fantastiskt land. Människorna är vänliga. Varmt och skönt. Vattnet och stränderna underbara.

reviews.title: SMALL CITY CENTER, FRIENDLY MARKET
reviews.text: WE TRAVELLED TO THE MARKET - TO ACTUALLY BUY AN ADAPTOR for my computer.  Whilst there we took the time to check out the market.  Alot of the artisans and tailors there are senegalese and the music yu hear blasted around you is also mainly Senegalese. Alot of second hand and chinese imports too (a growing scourge across our continent) and alot of colourful but  african outfits.  Despite the lack of tourists many items felt gearred to the tourist crowd. Not a very exciting market if you were to compare it to the kinds of fabric and tetxtile markets one sees in West Africa.

reviews.title: A must do
reviews.text: See,smell and hear how Gambians shop .A real experience This is a trip you could do on your own but a guide gives you so much information you would not otherwise know.

reviews.title: Busy Place
reviews.text: An interesting experience as you get to see how the locals trade and buy daily goods. It is however very food orientated so of limited interest to tourists. There are some craft stalls which sell local wood carvings and cloths - quality is good and we ended up buying a couple of articles to take home. The place is very crowded and could be a bit intimidating if you were on your own. We went with our taxi man plus a guy from the hotel so didn't experience any hassle from the bumsters. They also showed us around the town & port areas. Would recommend a short visit but take a minder.

reviews.title: Third World excitement.
reviews.text: This is an experience not to be missed. It's noisy and gives everyone a taste of the real Gambian experience. You'll only go once  cos' once is enough.

reviews.title: Lively Local Experience!
reviews.text:
A local guide is essential,but well worth the visit. A real taste of gambian atmosphere haggling for goods is a must aim for about half the asking price its fun and you'll get a great bargain. Everthing on offer clothes, shoes, trinkets, hand made arts and crafts goods wonderful array of local produce.
Will try to force you into deals or purchases but be firm and friendly if you dont want it say so!
Don't go on your own as the "bumsters" as they are known are relentless to tip or buy from them.

reviews.title: Textilier av högsta kvalitet
reviews.text: Overall in Gambia, the market is very popular with a wide variety of African samples, bad batik and traditional traditions. You can also visit the markets in Banjul, especially in the Albert Market. And av Västafrikas största. Alla ni som älskar tyger most åka hit! Här hittar ni allt. This can be done with your gardiner or an nan inredning, you can also have a unique look at the hotel. Come and stay at the same time and ask for money, even if you don't mind paying it. And it's a shame to be happy with it when it comes to hand. De är absolut inte sydda på ett sätt som guaranteed clear vår tvättmaskiner her hemma.

reviews.title: Visted to see local crafts
reviews.text: The friendliness of the people.  We went with a taxi driver who stopped any hassling by stall owners.

reviews.title: A busy, cozy, colorful market with its own unique culture
reviews.text: I found the Banjul market to be a bustling, vibrant, and colorful market with a unique culture. The fruit and clothing stalls were particularly appealing. Interacting with the locals was a wonderful experience. Be sure to clearly specify what you're looking for when making a purchase. All in all, a pleasant experience.

reviews.title: Get out of your hotel and see the people
reviews.text: this market is a must see, it's busy smelly and dirty, it's fantastic, it's great to see the local Gambians, rather than being stuck in your all inc hotel, bite the bullet get a taxi (very cheap) and go see the sights, we found it very safe.R

reviews.title: A must if you visit Gambia
reviews.text: Serrekunda market is huge so it a good idea to take a guide along to help you navigate, we spend a few hours at the Market experiencing the amazing sights sounds and smells never once did we feel threatened or had any hassle from the stall holders. Our guide Ba Ba I must say was marvellous and made sure we didn't get lost. Well worth a visit to see to have a real Gambian experience!

reviews.title: Good experience
reviews.text:
I probably chose one of the worst times to visit the market this year as it was rainy season, so the heat was pretty unbearable. Not the first time I have been to the market, and it surprises me every time I go. A very busy place, lots of items on offer from jewellery to cloth, watches to clothes and shoes. Please be cautious though it is very easy to get lost and with the heat dehydrated as well. The place is sprawling and if you don't take a trusted guide you will probably not enjoy it so much. It is quite an experience to visit such a busy place, but please be careful, the streets are a bit rough and you can lose yourself quite easily. I would advise not taking young children there as them getting lost could be a real problem. Take water and if you can find a trusted guide from one of the more well know hotels then take them also. You will find that once guided properly around you can enjoy some of the wonderful wares on offer, and also the prices, (if you haggle a bit then the prices can be really good). The atmosphere is pretty amazing, its just so busy and to be fair most people are friendly. Overall an experience that sometimes I enjoy, but when it is this hot not so much. 
Just remember: Take water
                          Take a guide
                          Don't take young children
                          Use your common sense when dealing with people

reviews.title: You must do, and even more
reviews.text: Banjul market is a must-see, but even better is exploring the markets with a local guide. Serecunda market, the market at the harbor—you'll need a local to find it and walk there from the harbor. You'll pass the sheep yards, if I may call them that, but there you can see how boats were repaired and made here in the past. I kind of lost my heart there in Gambia.

reviews.title: Local market
reviews.text:
You can find everything there. Food, clothes, spices, fabrics, fruit, chicken, presents, .....
do not forget to haggle.

reviews.title: My trip to The Gambia
reviews.text: A great place to visit if you enjoy a place that caters to the traditional family. There are wide range of food and items to get at the markets.

reviews.title: BOTHERED BY BANJUL MARKET'S MINDERS?!
reviews.text: BANJUL, GAMBIA 18 MARCH 2014 This country was made well-known to the world thanks to Alex Haley and his book “Roots” which was made into a television series, and tells the story of a native of The Gambia who is captured as a slave and sent to Virginia in the USA and the trials and tribulations of his life. Gambia which is only 4,360 square miles is the smallest country on the continent, and has a cooperative relationship with its neighbor Senegal, despite having separated from the federation of Senegambia in the early 1990's. Its first historical accounts come from the Arab traders in the 9th and 10th centuries, it was then taken over by the Portuguese who subsequently sold the trade rights to the British, becoming a colony in 1899, before finally becoming independent in February 1965. We didn't dock until around 11.00 am, so had a leisurely breakfast and a good sail in up The Gambia river. The shuttle bus service dropped us off in the city centre, at the Albert Market, where we went inside the market itself. This was almost a repeat of the other markets we had seen, particularly in Takoradi, and had the same produce as in Ghana. We then decided to stroll around the surrounding streets and we very shortly gained a "minder", who started to point out various buildings, as I was photographing. We had been warned by the ship that informal guides known as "bumsters" ahead. Initially we ignored him, but when it became too problematic, I told him to go away in Arabic, which not only surprised him, but also did the trick, and he melted away into the crowd. We then picked up yet another, who purported to be from "the security" force (which he wasn't); he had a badge round his neck to confirm it! He also proved a pain, and we stopped at some genuine police in the streets to ask the location of the internet café for which we were looking. Having made certain we were on the right track, we tried to ignore Mr. Less No. 2 only to find the original guy several paces ahead. So we then had two “minders” to ignore! Off the main thoroughfare, the streets were rubbish-strewn and potholed. Even though we were the only white people, we did not feel threatened because there were plenty of locals around. We eventually came to the Internet cafe and ascertained it would be US$1 for an hour. As the internet speed was really slow, and after checking there were no urgent emails, we left after 20 minutes, thereby fooling our two minders who may have been waiting outside when the hour had elapsed. On arrival back at the ship there were many stall holders displaying their wares on the quayside and I was tempted and bought a scarf. At 5.30pm in the evening the ship recorded the shade temperature as 99.7 F, - 38C!! However several hours later for deck barbecue, many people repaired to the dining room because of the very cold wind across the open decks, and the residual dining room staff had to be augmented by pool deck staff.

reviews.title: A Typical African Market
reviews.text: You should know how to haggle and bargain to get the best deal. You can buy African crafts or clothes.

reviews.title: Busy, busy, busy....
reviews.text: It's worth a visit, but be careful with photos. Not everyone enjoys being photographed! Otherwise, it's a bustling place where everyone is milling about.

reviews.title: Banjul market
reviews.text:
Banjul market is a big traditionel Gambian market. You can find there all kind of traditionel products like dryd fish, fruits, vegetables and flavors. you can also find a small part of handicraftwork, leather, clothes, wooden mask, animals and figures.
It is a very busy market, many Gambians are comming everyday to this nice market.

reviews.title: Serrekunda market
reviews.text: Locals and ex pats have renamed this market affectionately smellykunda !!! It is an experience anyone visiting gambia must try, the array of shops and stalls is immense tip take a guide with you to help barter with the stall holders and to negotiate the market as it is large and sprawling. A must visit, throughly enjoyable.

reviews.title: good market
reviews.text: Excellent market for material, and also for wood - best there is apart from Brikama... worth walking down on the beach towards the barra ferry as well - as this is an experience...

reviews.title: A walk down the lanes
reviews.text: We had our taxi driver as a guide for this trip. I think we would have got lost in all the little alleyways otherwise. It took us to lots of interesting stalls and it was fun battering with the stall holders who were all so friendly. Pity about the rubbish everywhere but this was typical of The Gambia. Put up with it and the place is so interesting. We saw school children, having finished school, learning the trade of making the colorful clothes worn in The Gambia and even smaller children carrying trays of water contained in small clear plastic bags which added to the rubbish. Noisy and cheerful. A great experience

reviews.title: Survive This and You Can Survive Anything
reviews.text:
Yep, that's how they advertise this incredible experience & how true that is... Bustling, vibvrant, colourful and simply out of this world. Welcome to The real Gambia my friend... Here at Banjul Market one can buy almost anything from a single colour nut to chew throughout the day to a hundredweight of sun-dried lady fish...Just watch where you put your feet. Surprisingly very little hassle, so don't worry. Keep moving and enjoy. We certainly did...

All Good Things, Neville & Jill Pettitt (England UK)

reviews.title: Great place to visit
reviews.text: What can I say we really enjoyed our trip here. Really busy market full of locals going about the their business. Well worth a trip to see how the smiling Gambians go about their stuff.

reviews.title: An experience!
reviews.text: We saw a bit of the real life of the people of Gambia as, with no fridges, market day is every day. Crowded and colourful with sights and smells we are not used to in our ultra hygienic world.

reviews.title: a sensory delight
reviews.text: Everybody should go to this market, it is a sensory delight. This is a must visit, as photos do not give you the different smells and sounds. Get a good guide and this experience you shall never forget.

reviews.title: Hectic, Crazy and fun
reviews.text: Don't mind everybody approaching you, that is a part of the experience. You see how the majority of the local Gambians make business and what they mainly sell. Always bargain.. 90% discount and you will achieve a fair price.

reviews.title: No hassle.
reviews.text: Quite an experience, loads to see and all sorts of things for sale, as usual if buying dont accept the first price, it is mainly for locals, but they are used to tourists. Perfectly safe, just use a little common sense re bags etc.

reviews.title: Just a market
reviews.text: Good idea to go with a Gambian so you will be left alone. Most things that a tourist would want to buy can be purchased from hotel shop or other street seller and you will get the same price all you have to do his haggle

reviews.title: Be careful of the pick pockets
reviews.text: Ok market, not so big as compared to the ones in Nigeria. However, good for sight seeing, buying also and having a feel of The Gambia.

reviews.title: et gambisk kaos...
reviews.text:
moro å gå rundt å se men ikke så altfor mye å bruke penger på;-)
Var gla vi hadde kjentmann med for markedet er en salig labyrint med utallige boder og MYE folk!

reviews.title: Wszystko w jednym miejscu
reviews.text: Fantastyczny targ z wyrobami rękodzieła regionalnego. Za niewielkie pieniądze, można zostać właścicielem pięknych wyrobów z drewna rzeźbionych na miejscu lub też tradycyjnych strojów gambijskich, koszy z baobabu, batiku itp

reviews.title: OK for a trip
reviews.text: The locals proudly say you can buy anything at this market.  But it looks more like a car boot sale than any market we are used to.  The crowds and stalls might look intimidating, but the locals are harmless (if overfriendly).  Personally, I was not impressed, but others might want to try the experience.

reviews.title: Look at all markets.
reviews.text:
Banjul market is great and really colourful but if you are in Kololi, Serrekunda is as good if not better. Also, have a look at the market at the top of the Senegambia strip. All prices are negotiable and don't be intimidated by the hard sell. Be in control.
Clothes can be made at very reasonable prices. Make a fair price that you feel you want to pay. If it's refused, walk away without being rude. You will get what you want .
Give it a try.

reviews.title: Fargerikt på markedet i Serrekunda
reviews.text: Serrekunda er Gambias største by og har ett stort marked som ikke er så 'turistifisert' som det i Banjul. Fantastisk utvalg i bla stoffer av alle slag til en rimelig penge. Ellers er det mye morsomt å se. For ikke å snakke om folkelivet.

reviews.title: what an eye opener!
reviews.text: this market is nothing like uk markets,and you need a strong stomach with most of it,if you like haggling then you"ll love it, seeing how Gambian people live and work in these markets is a right eye opener and you really appreciate how clean and tidy uk markets are.

reviews.title: Kaos på markedet
reviews.text: Å besøke marked in Banjul Gambia er en prøvelse.Det er skitten, støvete,masse selgere som vil ha tak i deg og det er ingenting å kjøpe for oss fra Europa, Pass på lommeboken og mobilen.Det er trengsel overalt.Det beste er å gå sammen med en local guide,da finner du ihvertfall tilbake hvor du kom fra.Aldri mer dit.

reviews.title: You should go!
reviews.text: Fun, fun, fun! Lots of great shooping, African clothes, drums  and gifts to bring home. Banjul is a small city and easy to get around. The beaches are fantstic, cheap hotels. Keep in mind that Gambia is a muslim country and it`s wise to dress properly in public areas. Friendly People.

reviews.title: Great Gambian experience!
reviews.text: large African market where you can find almost everything! It is large, so if you are worried about getting lost in the maze it might be a good idea to take a guide along. It is much less hectic and overcrowded than Serrekunda market and most of the alleyways are quite wide.
