Large craft market that carers for tourists, but  more selection and cheaper than most others I have visited. If you like vivid-coloured abstract African paintings, ask in the craft market for Ebrima Jaiteh and other stallholders will point you to his stall where he paints while you watch..

reviews.title: You just have to go
reviews.text: The market is difficult to describe; it's more of an experience than an attraction. I visited numerous times over a four month period between September and December while I was living in Serekunda and working in Banjul. My experience, and the way I was treated by vendors and others, evolved over four months I was there. At the end, although I was never a native, I was no longer a complete outsider or merely a tourist.

reviews.title: Nice to visit a market in Africa
reviews.text: The market in Banjul has a wide variety of items, vegetables, meat, fish, but also clothes, household items and a lot of tourist items, including beautiful wood carvings.

reviews.title: Market Trip
reviews.text: Go very early in the morning and there is not to much hassling, very dirty and noisy, once in a lifetime visit never to be repeated again.

reviews.title: Original African market
reviews.text: You'll love it, with its many narrow streets and a variety of restaurants. Just be sure to watch your wallet.

reviews.title: Market
reviews.text: A very busy market place with everybody selling everything, nice experience. Barter! barter!! barter!!!

reviews.title: An experience not to miss.
reviews.text: As the title says, this is a not to be missed experience.  Allow yourself plenty of time, it is a maze and you will be sharpening up your bartering skills before you know it. Don't just look at the tourist areas, have a look at the food market as well, Tesco's will never seem the same again. Remember not to show too much money or it will seriously affect your bartering power.

reviews.title: An interesting ethnic experience but not necessarily a pleasant one
reviews.text: Banjul market is a crowded rather insanitary traditional African market. You will need to be firm to avoid "bumsters" trying to act as go-betweens and consequently hiking the prices for their own unseen commission while expecting a tip form you afterwards. Most of what is on sale is poor quality Chinese produce. Watch your personal belongings in the narrow alleyways and be sure to take a very tough line in bartering in the unlikely event that you see something worth buying.

reviews.title: Nice and quiet
reviews.text: If you're staying in the tourist area, a trip to Banjul is wonderful. You can see "authentic" Gambia, and people here are more likely to leave you alone. You'll occasionally be approached, but it's not very disruptive.

reviews.title: market
reviews.text: It's nice to see how the locals do their shopping, but the market in Serrakunda is much bigger and also a lot busier...

reviews.title: Banjul Market
reviews.text:
Bustling and colourful ,friendly and interesting ,but the stallholders will do Anything to make a sale,and will chat for ages.
We went with a guide and were surprised how many aunts sisters and cousins he had running stalls . When we joked about it he said 'we Gambians are ALL family at heart '

reviews.title: busy local market
reviews.text: A nice local market with lots of things for sale. It's best to go with a guide, as it's very busy and everyone wants to sell you something.

reviews.title: THE REAL GAMBIA
reviews.text: Banjul market is a bustling and noisy place which some tourists are not really prepared for as they approach the experience with their own country's mindset. If people want to see the country as it is, an open mind is needed. Here is the real Gambia and an active one where people are putting a lot of effort into earning a living. Gambians are hard working people. There is no state benefits system such as that in the UK, so the people in Gambia are very resourceful and productive. The tourists really need to support their enterprise. Comparing it to shopping experiences in the tourists' home country is unfair and unrealistic. Tourists know the price of goods in their home country but many are not willing to pay the price when they go there and even expect to under-pay. They see the local traders as "husslers" though they are just trying to make a living and they put a lot of efffort into it. I would encourage tourists to support local industry, but also to do as they do at home - shop around! Get friendly with a local person who knows where the bargains are. Gambian ladies are always good to know and helpful, telling people where to find the best price for something they want to buy. Banjul market is good, but also try Senegambia Craft Market on the Bertil Harding Highway.

reviews.title: Interesting, but not for sensitive Europeans...
reviews.text: We originally planned to explore the Royal Albert Market on our own, but luckily, we were with our taxi driver. He guided us around and out again. The heat and the intense smell of fish in the narrow, partially covered aisles are not for the faint-hearted. Anyone who has taken a peek into the slaughterhouse will look forward to seeing the fat, grumpy saleswoman at their local meat counter again...

reviews.title: An experience
reviews.text: Very noisy and at times smelly.  Bustling and active.  Every thing you need is there somewhere!  Well worth a vist.

reviews.title: Many stalls, many souvenirs
reviews.text: The market seems to cater primarily to tourists; there are countless souvenir stalls selling the same old items. However, you can watch how the items are made—everything is handmade. The alleys between the stalls are very narrow, making it difficult to navigate. All in all, along with the adjacent marina, it's the most interesting place in Banjul.

reviews.title: its an experience
reviews.text: There has been a lot of work done to stop this being such a nightmare for tourists from what I understand, we had our taxi driver with us but did not feel in the least bit intimidated. If it were like shopping in Asda......there would be no point!! relax and enjoy....

reviews.title: wouldnt go again
reviews.text: for some people it may be a great experience but personally i felt like it wasn't something they wanted us to see. ive been to many locals markets while travelling a few years ago, but i dont think the locals want you there so it just makes it uncomfortable for both parties. my suggestion just dont bother going...or just drive past it.

reviews.title: well worth a visit
reviews.text:
a trip to banjul market is an eye opener if you have never visited an African market before.
you can buy almost anyting you want , but remember to haggle.also take a guide with you or you may be a long time finding your way out

reviews.title: As hectic as ever
reviews.text: If you've been here before and feel confident about bartering, there really is no need to have the taxi driver come with you. However, if it's your first time you may feel less intimidated if you have a little 'help.'

reviews.title: market
reviews.text: Al ways go to the market take local person with you this way you don;t get overcharged and they are very helpfull at bartering for taxi ect

reviews.title: Artwork
reviews.text: I bought some great artwork and the vendors were a lot more layed back than those in other areas. I found lots of examples of unique pieces of canvasses and the locals were happy to make alterartions to some of the leather goods I purchased. I would say its a nice place to pass through rather than spend a extended period.

reviews.title: Very upsetting
reviews.text: Very dirty and hot, open stalls with blood dripping meat flung over make shift stalls, covered in hunfreds of flies, second hand clothes stalls and ladies selling fish and veg again everything covered in flies, not for the fainthearted

reviews.title: a must see market
reviews.text: this is a very eye opening place and certainly a busy one. i didnt enjoy the fish and meat part of the market because of the smell and to many flys

reviews.title: Good place to walk around and get a good bargain.
reviews.text: Banjul Market is mainly a craft market with loads of wooden items, paintings, fabrics and similar products. I would recommend going with a guide or a local taxi driver because they can help you barter for items and lead you to the right section if you are looking for a particular item. Banjul market is better than Serekunda if you are looking for gifts however if you want fabric I would recommend going to Serekunda instead because you tend to get better deals on fabrics in Serekunda.

reviews.title: a rabbit warren
reviews.text: It was quite dark inside like a rabbit warren, but the stall holders were very helpful. If they didnt have what you wanted, they knew someone who did! Worth a visit just for the experience.

reviews.title: lots to see
reviews.text: crafts you can do or watch tie and dye being done and then have a  chance to purchase any of the goods. wood crafts are excellent and an art in there selves.

reviews.title: Well Worth a Visit
reviews.text: We used a Green tourist taxi and went on our own as opposed to going via organized tour guide. We like to do our thing in our own time. The taxi cost 700 dalassi £14, the driver stayed with us all the time and walked us around the market. Which was great because a.) he knew his way around so we did not get lost & b.) he made sure that we did not get hassled, he also explained to us the way the market runs and explained what the produce was that was on sale. He then walked us along the beach to the port and back via the fishing village. A big eye opener on how they live and just how poor they really are.

reviews.title: Great place to make friends
reviews.text:
The market traders are great people to get to know. I take their photographs whenever I go there but only after asking permission.
The vital part is to give them copies of the photos on your return.
There are some very beautiful people there.
A modelling agency could fill their books.
Watch out for the wheelbarrows!

reviews.title: Local market. Must see it.
reviews.text: I good market to start with. There is a bigger one in Serrakunda. You will need a guide that will help you around on both places. We recommend that you take a guide and a driver. Then you and the gudie can focus on the trip. No problem with parking etc. With some tour companies you will get this city tour for free if you book two full day tours. We can recommend 4*4 south gambia and the safari in senegal. We used www.bushwhackertours.com with an excellent guide called JJ. We went on four trips with him. He was very good at adjusting the trip after our needs. Well educated in history and local culture.

reviews.title: another nice snack
reviews.text: not bad but give us the Serrekunda market. There is something to see but take a taxi and go to Bakau fish market or Tanji (definitely worth a visit)

reviews.title: nothing great
reviews.text: it is nothing great - typcial west african market. but if you have not been to any before, then it is worth a visit. But bargain hard :)

reviews.title: Fish section - if you have a strong stomach
reviews.text: Exciting place with so  many things to see. The fish section however was a challenge. As there is no cooling, fish are covered with flies and the smell is very very intense.

reviews.title: Market
reviews.text: The market was extremely clean considering how many stalls there were. It's a must. Lovely people, but you can't buy from them all!

reviews.title: Must do
reviews.text:
This is a not-to-be-missed experience, the colours, the smells and of course, the people.
Go with a guide.

reviews.title: busy busy
reviews.text: lots of things to see here, mostly local hand made goods, shopkeepers were nice and chatty, not too much hassle but bartering part of the fun, worth a visit

reviews.title: Very local non-touristy
reviews.text: Absalutely huge.  We did not stay long as didn't really want to buy. It is packed, smelly and very local. However it is an experience to maybe try!!!

reviews.title: Good
reviews.text: A lovely little market, but you get hassled ALOT!! Be prepared to have people coming at you from all different directions trying to sell you their goods!!

reviews.title: Che posto...
reviews.text: Mercato fantastico, quelli che si lamentano di fango e puzza vadano nei grandi centri commerciali...  trovi tutto cio' che riguarda vestiario e tant'altro... Consigliat andare con qualcuno del posto.... Piu' che altro per contrattare meglio... Sai com'e'....:-)

reviews.title: Colourful and and Busy
reviews.text:
Very busy and colourful, and very smelly (not for the faint hearted)
The craft part at the back of the market is full of stalls selling local crafts but haggle the prices are high.

reviews.title: 3 Main Markets at Banjul Market
reviews.text:
Fish Market
Art & Crafts Market
Fruit & Veg Market

All reasonably close to each other and worth asking for local prices before entering any of the markets for a fair price.

reviews.title: a busy bustling local market full of colour
reviews.text: Banjul Market is a large busy,very hot market,where you really need a guide to take you round,to avoid getting too much attention,and to help with bartering and to find your way round.Theres a lot of local colour,some of the fish/meat stalls can be a bit aromotic but this all adds to the excitement of being in an African market,thats more for locals rather than a tourist trap.This is a great stop off if you are visiting Banjul for a taste of local life with friendly smiling stall holders all trying to sell their goods to you.

reviews.title: Adventurous
reviews.text:
The market in Banjul is worth a trip, just driving thrue Banjul will give you an insight on what an African City means.
Lots of things to see and buy in the market.
It's a real Gambian market, not a tourist trap.

reviews.title: Never travel to Banjul, Gambia
reviews.text: Extremely dirty muddy place and on top of it  - it is dangerous due to no police or other control. Never eat here and drink only bottled water.

reviews.title: Worth visiting
reviews.text: Good and cheap gifts.  Can barter with the locals, to get the best price. Well worth visiting the markets.

reviews.title: Beautifull market but not if you're alone!
reviews.text: Banjul has a beautifull craftmarket where you can buy lots of beautifull craft, such as, batik, woodcarvings, paintings and others. Unfortunatly we where the only ones at the market beacause it was still low season. Everybody is convincing you that they got the nicest shop. Be carefull cause the guides may close a deal with the salesmen and you pay a to high price.

reviews.title: Great market
reviews.text: Nothing like our markets. So many people, so many animals, it's dirty, and if you're alone, you could easily get lost.

reviews.title: A must experience
reviews.text:
Yes it might be overwhelming or even unpleasant at times but to not visit the Albert Market in Banjul would be missing out on the essence of what this place is about. It is a fantastic assault on the sences, best take a local with you and get him to keep you out of the tourist section, no hassel from sellers then as they know you wont want what they sell! 
Dont miss the fish and meat sections.........
Carefull who you point your camera at though, the attention is not always welcome.

reviews.title: Little diversity
reviews.text: If you're looking for souvenirs, you can get them here. Be sure to bring a guide who can haggle for you. They have wood carvings, paintings, and batik fabrics.

reviews.title: Busy Busy Busy
reviews.text: A busy market full of noise and colour, watch out for pick pockets !!!!..... better to take a local tourist guide with you........... you have to barter for everything be prepared to get hassled to buy  but all part of the experience, it can get very hot in the center of Banjul make sure you take water with you

reviews.title: Horrible!
reviews.text: Very dirty and smelly market...not sure of the exact reason it is included as a place to visit! It was probably for people to shop but believe me, it wasnt worth the stress at all.

reviews.title: Nice tourist market for souvenirs
reviews.text: If you're looking for fun souvenirs, you can find them here. Every shop has the same thing, but this means you can haggle...if you dare!

reviews.title: Colour and vibrant
reviews.text:
Went round the market looking for fabric.
The market is full of colour and real Banjul life, when going around the market you have some attention. However prepare to be hassled in the craft market, however it is all good fun. If you do not like meat or fish smells avoid this area

reviews.title: Nothing special really
reviews.text: We booked a taxi driver for the day & he brought us here to look around. My mom wanted to look at designer bags (which are fake here) but he brought us to the more local-market and we felt kind of uncomfortable in those narrow alleyways between stands and everyone looked at us. It smelled bad, too. He brought us to a stand with leather bags which were nice but I don't like to bargain and to be fair, I don't want a bag in the shape of a voodoo doll when I get back to Holland. So we asked our guide to bring us back to the main street. He didn't know what we meant with designer bags and seemed a bit lost so after two shops (who were nice and airconditioned) we asked to go. Prior to this we bought some fabric at a stand where our guide bargained for us so we could buy the nice fabric to be tailored into dresses. We paid 800 dalasi for 2 pieces. We had it tailored at the Senegambia hotel by Aida for 1350 (not each, but in total).

reviews.title: Great place but full on!
reviews.text: i loved visiting the markets, they are buzzing so it can be full on at times as everyone tries to sell you things as you are a tourist. Don't get caught up in this, only pick up things if you are interested otherwise you may find yourself stuck there for a lot longer than you want to be! make sure you take water as it gets hot walking around the markets during the day with the heat. If you aren't one for seeing animals (ie butchers/fishmongers) be warned you will come across stalls like this with everything out on the floor.... it's the way it is done so cover your nose and close your mouth to avoid the strong smells. Just remember you are seeing the reality which is definitely in technicolour in this place - Fab!

reviews.title: Bumster nightmare
reviews.text: Aggressively hassled and harassed by bumsters, security guards and stall holders.  Will never return.

reviews.title: WHAT AN EXPERIENCE
reviews.text: The local just dont let you get on with just browsing

reviews.title: Local flavours - good and bad!
reviews.text:
Visiting the local market/souk or whatever they are called are always a must when traveling to exotic places - and the Banjul market as such resembles what you will find across Africa. It is hectic, noisy, smelly - and so interesting!

Obviously you have to fight off the beggars once in a while, but if you go with a determined mind they are not too hard to get rid off. It is not easy to know when you can take a picture and when not - and your eyes see so many things, your camera wishes to bring back home. But mostly you will have to keep those memories in your head to not risk offending the locals. 

If however you shop non-tourist items you will not have to bargain, and the experience will be so much nicer. I brought back plastic dishes, mugs etc. at the ridiculous price of 30-40 euro cents each, and the seller did everything to make me happy finding the exact color and pattern I wanted!

It is however recommended to bring your taxi driver, as you will otherwise find yourselves with a lot of people talking to you only to later claim you own them money for guidance!

reviews.title: AN EXPERIENCE
reviews.text:
a  busy market full of noise and colour, watch your pockets.
this is where you have to barter for everything,people great, goods great.

reviews.title: dirty crowded
reviews.text: oh my  god what can you  say  dirty  cheap tatt and  very pressured to buy. Its  almost threatening

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: You do get hassled alot but worth a visit. You can get a local yellow and green taxi there and there are plenty of taxi available to get back to your hotel

reviews.title: Disgusting and pushy
reviews.text: The market is just plain disgusting. Lots of rotten fish and vegetables being sold, the stench is unbearable. The craftmarket is full of pushy people, just dragging you by your arm into their stores. They say they're offended if you don't look around, but their even worse when you do. We just left.

reviews.title: Albert  fish n fly market!?!
reviews.text: Although the craft market offers some unusual locally made goods,the rest of the market on the whole,is there to serve the locals with "fresh" local produce.It can be very "aromatic" and hot,very busy with locals "on their missions",but on the outskirts are some very good trading outlets,(all round the city of Banjul),so best to wander or explore and avoid the market early morning.Once ventured never forgotten folks?

reviews.title: The only interesting thing about Banjul
reviews.text: Banjul is an inhospitable and harsh city. Nowhere in Gambia is unsafe, not because of a lack of security. But because of the rawness of life exposed there to the sight, smell, and sensitivity of the traveler. The market is incredible. A must-see. Not just to buy (which is also a must, if you want to buy African chickens, used shoes, lamb heads, baobab powder, or various crafts...). It's a place out of time, with a sensorial power impossible to find in "rich" Europe, and with such authentic humanity that it will make you think, and you won't be able to forget.

reviews.title: Busy, crowded, hot and scruffy, but worth a visit
reviews.text:
This market mixes local and touristy things to purchase, you are hassled a bit, but no where near as bad as Egypt. The title says it all really, but you do need to bargain hard, as they will just try to get as much from you as they can. We always take our friendly taxi driver with us, who gives us an idea of the price to pay, though he does this away from the vendor as they will accuse him of spoiling their business.
A far better and larger market to get a feel of real Gambia is Brikama, this is a proper local market and you will not be hassled at all, though there are few touristy things here, there is a local craft centre nearby.

reviews.title: Take a guide
reviews.text: Use the local hotel tourist guide for this very busy and narrow market - its fantastic.  Sharpen your bargaining skills,

reviews.title: A vibrant colourful market
reviews.text: Take a Government Guide (yellow shirts and a badge) and you can look around freely without any hassle.  Fascinating insite into the Banjul way of life.

reviews.title: Africa at its best!
reviews.text:
Albert Market is in Banjul on Liberation Avenue - a must for every visitor to Gambia. Very busy, very crowded and typycal African. Most parts of the market are just for the local needs and not covering the typical touristic stuff. 
I really enjoyed the atmophere, smell and sounds. However if you are not used to african Markets at least the fish and meat section may be a very different experience.
One of the few must does in Banjul!

reviews.title: Suggested Green shopping - and save a life or two!
reviews.text: Why go to a Gambian market and not buy something? Why not buy something and avoid the hassle of carrying it home? Why not buy something that will make an excellent gift and save a life in the process? I'm suggesting that you visit Banjul market - go by bush taxi (part of the experience) and when you arrive walk along Old Perseverance Street in Albert Market until you come to the shop of Manneh Suwareh, dealer in 'bednets' - mosquito nets, in other words. The nets are well made locally, come in various shades and styles and make superb, life-saving gifts to your favorite hotel staff, village schools, hospitals or casual strangers. Mosquitoes kill people. We take anti-malarials and tend not to visit during the rainy season. Gambian village houses are built to let hot air out, Sadly, this enables mozzies to fly in. Buy a net, give a gift, save a life. Cost? About 200D - the price of a few drinks, and a fraction of the cost you would pay back home. Manneh is a lovely man; he won't rob you - and you'll probably get a conducted tour of the market thrown in.
